items.name: TikTok videos that change based on what you watch
items.explanation: TikTok uses AI to learn what videos you like and recommends similar ones. It watches what you watch, like, and skip to figure out your preferences.

items.name: Snapchat filter that changes your face
items.explanation: Snapchat filters use AI to detect your face, find your eyes, nose, and mouth, then add effects that move with you in real-time.

items.name: Voice on a smart speaker answering questions
items.explanation: Smart speakers like Alexa and Google Home use AI to understand your voice, figure out what you're asking, and find the right answer.

items.name: Video game character that learns how you play
items.explanation: Some video games use AI to make characters smarter. They learn your playing style and adapt to make the game more challenging or fun.

items.name: Robot vacuum cleaner moving by itself
items.explanation: Robot vacuums use AI to map your home, avoid obstacles, and figure out the best path to clean every spot without getting stuck.

items.name: Automatic captions on YouTube videos
items.explanation: YouTube uses AI called speech recognition to listen to videos and automatically write out what people are saying as text captions.

items.name: Phone unlocking with your face
items.explanation: Face unlock uses AI to recognise your unique facial features. It can tell the difference between you and other people, or even a photo of you!

items.name: Translation app that listens and speaks in another language
items.explanation: Translation apps use AI to understand speech in one language and convert it to another. They learn from millions of translated sentences.

items.name: A storybook you read at home
items.explanation: A printed storybook is just paper with ink. It doesn't learn, change, or respond to you - the words stay the same every time you read it.

items.name: A bicycle you ride to school
items.explanation: A bicycle is powered by you! It uses simple machines like gears, chains, and wheels - no computer brain needed.

items.name: A toaster that browns bread
items.explanation: A toaster uses a simple timer and heating element. It doesn't learn or think - it just heats up for the time you set.

items.name: A radio that plays music when you turn it on
items.explanation: A basic radio receives signals from radio stations and converts them to sound. It doesn't make decisions or learn your preferences.

items.name: A regular TV remote
items.explanation: A TV remote just sends simple signals to your TV when you press buttons. It doesn't understand or learn anything.

items.name: A printed photo album
items.explanation: A photo album is just printed pictures in a book. Unlike phone photos apps, it can't recognise faces or organise pictures automatically.

items.name: A flashlight that turns on with a switch
items.explanation: A flashlight is a simple circuit - flip the switch, and electricity flows to make light. No thinking involved!

items.name: A clock with hands that tick
items.explanation: An analog clock uses gears and springs (or a small motor) to move the hands. It tells time through mechanical movement, not intelligence.
